description: The Israeli military said that one of its airstrikes earlier this month killed Hashem Safieddine. There was no immediate confirmation from the militant group about the fate of top official.
title: Israel says it killed a top Hezbollah official expected to be the group's next leader

description:
More than a fifth of Lebanon's population is now displaced, mostly fleeing from the country's south as Israel carries out airstrikes against the Iran-backed group Hezbollah there. With so many people out of their homes, they're taking refuge anywhere they can, including in one of Beirut's most popular nightclubs. Our reporter in Lebanon introduces us to some of the displaced.

For more coverage of all sides of this conflict, go to npr.org/mideastupdates.
title: A Nightclub Turned Shelter in Beirut

description: The magazine said the two parties agreed to part ways, though an investigation found no inaccuracies or bias in Nuzzi’s reporting. Meanwhile, Nuzzi and her ex-fiancé are blaming each other in court.
title: Olivia Nuzzi and 'New York Magazine' have split over her relationship with RFK Jr.

description: New reports from Physicians for Human Rights and Doctors Without Borders document a "massive influx" of sexual violence in the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. What can be done to stop it?
title: Why this country is seeing a 'staggering' increase in the number of rapes

description: Five people, including three teenagers, are dead after a Monday morning shooting in a home in Fall City, Wash. A 15-year-old male was taken into custody.
title: 5 people are dead and a teenager is in custody after a shooting in Washington state

description: A video making lurid and false claims about the Democratic presidential candidate was spread by pro-Trump accounts. Intelligence officials say Russia was behind the video.
title: U.S. intel officials says Russia is behind attempts to smear Tim Walz

description: Honda said there are no reports of injuries or deaths related to the issue. It is the second major call this month at Honda, after 1.7 million vehicles were found to have potential steering issues.
title: Honda recalls 700,000 Accords, Civics and CR-Vs for fuel pumps that can leak

description: New Yorker writer Susan Glasser says Trump is highly transactional, so billionaires may be betting on access and a seat at the table if he’s re-elected. It’s what some of them got in his first term.
title: What do Elon Musk and other billionaires want in return for backing Trump?

description: A new poll from the American Psychological Association shows 7 out of 10 adults say the future of the Nation is a significant source of stress in their lives. And the results cross party lines.
title: A divided country agrees: The election is stressing everyone out

description: Lee Hsien Yang, the brother of Singapore's former prime minister, said he is a "political refugee" after the U.K. government granted him asylum from what he described as persecution at home.
title: The son of Singapore's founder says he has been granted political asylum in the U.K.

description: As results roll in on election night, Pennsylvania's may take a while longer. Here's why that is. And, the ACLU challenges Louisiana's Ten Commandments law saying it harms children.
title: Pennsylvania election results may take days to count. And, ACLU fighting Louisiana law

description: An NPR investigation has found that since 2022, Trump has repeatedly threatened to investigate, prosecute, jail or otherwise punish his political opponents, rivals and even private citizens.
title: Trump has made more than 100 threats to prosecute or punish perceived enemies

description: Some clinics will now check your breast scan for arterial calcification, which can be a sign of heart disease risk. But questions remain about the approach.
title: What your mammogram can tell you about your cardiovascular health

description: Lt. Cmdr. Lyndsay “Miley” Evans and Lt. Serena “Dug” Wileman were both 31 and from California, and recently served nine months on a tour in Yemen.
title: 2 naval aviators died in a plane crash after returning from a tour in Yemen

description: NPR's Michel Martin speaks with Pennsylvania's top elections official, Al Schmidt, about how the commonwealth is preparing for the Election Day vote count.
title: Pennsylvania's top elections official on conspiracies, the voting process and what to expect on election night

description: NPR's Michel Martin speaks with Pennsylvania's top elections official, Al Schmidt, about how the commonwealth is preparing for the Election Day vote count.
title: Why election results from the battleground state of Pennsylvania may take a while

description: The Neighborhood Assistance Corporation of America, which helps members get affordable mortgages, says its 3.7 million members must vote or risk losing membership — and the financial benefits.
title: An organization has novel way to get members to vote. But is it legal?

description: Ukraine is suffering from more than a Russian invasion. Births have plummeted. But many families with help from the government and doctors are trying to buck the trend and have a child in wartime.
title: As Ukraine's birth rate plunges, here's what one doctor is doing to reverse the trend

description: As Samantha Hodge-Williams waited on the operating table for emergency surgery, she felt alone and scared. Then the anesthesiologist appeared.
title: She was terrified waiting for surgery. Then her anesthesiologist began to sing

description: Peru’s former President Alejandro Toledo was sentenced to 20 years and six months in prison in a case involving construction giant Odebrecht that became synonymous with corruption in Latin America.
title: Peru’s ex-president Toledo gets more than 20 years in prison in case linked to corruption scandal

description: Marcelo Pérez continued to work as a peace activist despite threats. Advocates say he did not receive the government protection he needed.
title: Hundreds mourn Catholic priest and Indigenous peace activist killed in southern Mexico

description: The family of Jayland Walker, a Black man who was fatally shot by eight police officers, will receive a $4.8 million settlement from the city of Akron, the mayor's office said.
title: Akron to pay $4.8 million to Jayland Walker's family over police shooting
